Hello! I am Daewon.
----
안녕하세요 (annyeonghaseyo) = Hello (formal)
• Polite/formal greeting
• Use with anyone you don't know well

More examples:
• 안녕하세요, 선생님! (Hello, teacher!)
• 안녕하세요, 만나서 반갑습니다. (Hello, nice to meet you.)

Hi! Friend!
----
안녕 (annyeong) = Hi/Bye (informal)
• Casual greeting/farewell
• Only use with close friends or younger people

More examples:
• 안녕, 잘 가! (Bye, take care!)

Thank you for helping me.
----
감사합니다 (gamsahamnida) = Thank you (formal)
• Most formal/polite way to say thank you
• Safe to use in any situation

More examples:
• 정말 감사합니다! (Thank you so much!)

Thank you for helping me.
----
고맙습니다 (gomapseumnida) = Thank you (formal, alternative)
• Slightly warmer than 감사합니다
• Common in spoken Korean

More examples:
• 정말 고맙습니다! (Thank you so much!)

Thank you for helping me.
----
감사해요 (gamsahaeyo) = Thank you (polite)
• Polite but less formal
• Good for everyday use

More examples:
• 많이 감사해요! (Thanks a lot!)

Thank you for helping me.
----
고마워요 (gomawoyo) = Thank you (polite, alternative)
• Warm and friendly
• Common in daily conversations

More examples:
• 정말 고마워요! (Thanks so much!)

I'm sorry for being late.
----
죄송합니다 (joesonghamnida) = I'm sorry (formal)
• Most formal apology
• Use in professional or serious situations

More examples:
• 실수해서 죄송합니다. (I'm sorry for the mistake.)

I'm sorry for being late.
----
미안합니다 (mianhamnida) = I'm sorry (formal, alternative)
• Sincere apology
• Common in formal situations

More examples:
• 정말 미안합니다. (I'm really sorry.)

Sorry for being late.
----
미안해요 (mianhaeyo) = Sorry (polite)
• Everyday polite apology
• Use with friends, colleagues

More examples:
• 미안해요, 잊어버렸어요. (Sorry, I forgot.)

That's right, yes.
----
네 (ne) = Yes
• Polite affirmative
• Can also mean "I'm listening"

More examples:
• 네, 알겠습니다. (Yes, I understand.)
• 네, 맞습니다. (Yes, that's correct.)

No, that's not right.
----
아니요 (aniyo) = No
• Polite negative
• Can be shortened to 아니

More examples:
• 아니요, 괜찮아요. (No, it's okay.)
• 아니요, 학생이 아닙니다. (No, I'm not a student.)

I study Korean.
----
저 (jeo) = I (humble/polite)
• Humble form of "I"
• Use in formal/polite situations

Compare: 나 (na) = I (casual)

I am a student.
----
저는 (jeoneun) = I (topic marker)
• 저 (I) + 는 (topic particle)
• "As for me..."

More examples:
• 저는 대원이에요. (I am Daewon.)
• 저는 미국 사람입니다. (I am American.)

I am a student.
----
입니다 (imnida) = am/is/are (formal)
• Formal copula (to be)
• Attach directly to noun

More examples:
• 이것은 책입니다. (This is a book.)
• 그는 선생님입니다. (He is a teacher.)

I am a student.
----
이에요/예요 (ieyo/yeyo) = am/is/are (polite)
• Polite copula (to be)
• 이에요 after consonant, 예요 after vowel

More examples:
• 이것은 책이에요. (This is a book.)
• 저는 대원이에요. (I am Daewon.)

My name is Daewon.
----
이름 (ireum) = name
• Noun

More examples:
• 이름이 뭐예요? (What's your name?)
• 당신의 이름은? (Your name?)

My name is Daewon.
----
제 (je) = my
• 저 (I) + possessive form
• Humble possessive

More examples:
• 제 친구 (my friend)
• 제 책 (my book)

Nice to meet you!
----
만나서 반갑습니다 (mannaseo bangapseumnida) = Nice to meet you
• Fixed expression
• 만나다 (to meet) + 반갑다 (to be glad)

More examples:
• 만나서 반가워요! (Nice to meet you! - polite)

One, two, three!
----
하나 (hana) = 1 (native Korean)
• Use for: counting objects, age, hours
• Changes to 한 before counters

More examples:
• 하나, 둘, 셋, 넷! (1, 2, 3, 4!)
• 한 개 (one item)

One, two, three!
----
둘 (dul) = 2 (native Korean)
• Use for: counting objects, age, hours
• Changes to 두 before counters

More examples:
• 두 개 (two items)
• 두 시 (2 o'clock)

One, two, three!
----
셋 (set) = 3 (native Korean)
• Use for: counting objects, age, hours
• Changes to 세 before counters

More examples:
• 세 개 (three items)
• 세 시 (3 o'clock)

Four, five, six
----
넷 (net) = 4 (native Korean)
• Changes to 네 before counters

다섯 (daseot) = 5
여섯 (yeoseot) = 6

More examples:
• 네 개 (four items)
• 다섯 살 (5 years old)

Seven, eight, nine
----
일곱 (ilgop) = 7 (native Korean)
여덟 (yeodeol) = 8
아홉 (ahop) = 9

More examples:
• 일곱 시 (7 o'clock)
• 여덟 개 (8 items)

One, two, ..., ten!
----
열 (yeol) = 10 (native Korean)
• Base for 11-19: 열 + number
• 열하나 (11), 열둘 (12), etc.

More examples:
• 열 시 (10 o'clock)
• 열다섯 (15)

1, 2, 3, 4, 5
----
일 (il) = 1 (Sino-Korean)
이 (i) = 2
삼 (sam) = 3
사 (sa) = 4
오 (o) = 5

Use for: dates, money, phone numbers, minutes

More examples:
• 일월 (January)
• 천 원 (1000 won)

6, 7, 8, 9
----
육 (yuk) = 6 (Sino-Korean)
칠 (chil) = 7
팔 (pal) = 8
구 (gu) = 9

More examples:
• 육월 (June)
• 칠천 원 (7000 won)

1, 2, ..., 10!
----
십 (ship) = 10 (Sino-Korean)
• Base for teens: 십 + number
• 십일 (11), 십이 (12), etc.

More examples:
• 십오 분 (15 minutes)
• 이십 (20 = 2×10)

20, 30, 40...
----
이십 (iship) = 20 (Sino-Korean)
• Pattern: number + 십
• 삼십 (30), 사십 (40), 오십 (50)
• 육십 (60), 칠십 (70), 팔십 (80), 구십 (90)

More examples:
• 이십오 분 (25 minutes)
• 삼십 일 (30 days)

1, 10, 100, 1000
----
백 (baek) = 100 (Sino-Korean)
천 (cheon) = 1000
• Used for counting money, large numbers

More examples:
• 백 원 (100 won)
• 천 원 (1000 won)
• 이천 (2000)
